1. REF: the social card of residents of Ivanovo region is to be recognised as an electronic payment instrument .

    HYP: a social card from the Ivanovo region is recognized as electronic means of payment .


  2. REF: these changes make allowances for the preservation of discounted travel on public transportation .

    HYP: the amendments stipulate the preservation of the privileges on travel in the public passenger transport .


  3. REF: starting on September 24 , the organisation of discounted travel for citizens of Ivanovo region using the social card will change .

    HYP: on September , 24 changes of the order of organization of preferential access of citizens using the social card of the resident of Ivanovo region .


  4. REF: the press service for the Government of Russia for Ivanovo region reports that the changes make allowances for the preservation of discounted travel on public transportation and introduce a system of mutual settlements on the social card in accordance with the requirements of Federal Law No . 161 `` On the National Payment System '' .

    HYP: according to the press service of the government of Russia on Ivanovo region , changes stipulate the preservation of the privileges on travel in the public passenger transport and lead the scheme of mutual settlements on the social card in accordance with the requirements of Federal Law No . 161 Federal Law `` On National Payment System . ''


  5. REF: moreover , the social card of residents of Ivanovo region is to be recognised as an electronic payment instrument .

    HYP: in this case , the social card from the Ivanovo region is recognized as electronic means of payment .


  6. REF: accordingly , the conditions of its use will change .

    HYP: accordingly , the terms of its application change .


  7. REF: for example , the loading limit is no longer set according to trips as before , but rather according to an amount of money ; and the winter and summer periods will be maintained : in the winter , it will be no more than 400 roubles , and , in the summer , no more than 800 roubles for a given month .

    HYP: thus , the deposit limit is set now not on trips , as before , but in the amount of money , with the preservation of winter and summer periods - in winter not more than 400 rubles , during the summer period - no more than 800 rubles for the current month .


  8. REF: now , when they are issued a transit receipt , social card holders will need to keep track of the balance of funds on the card and not the number of remaining trips .

    HYP: now owners of the social card will have to track not the amount of the remaining trips , but the rest of the money .


  9. REF: the cost of discounted travel for citizens will amount to 1/2 the fare of the applicable carrier .

    HYP: the cost of preferential fare for citizens will be 1/2 of the fare operated by the carrier .


  10. REF: the other half of the fare will be paid for from the regional budget .

    HYP: the remaining half of the fare will be reimbursed by the regional budget .


  11. REF: the schedule for topping up the social card with funds will stay the same : during the period between the 24th of the previous month through to the 23rd of the current month .

    HYP: the rate of replenishment of the social card is still the same - in the period from 24 numbers of the previous month to 23 the current month .


  12. REF: the new procedure for travelling with a social card will have a number of advantages .

    HYP: a new setting on the social map will have a number of advantages .


  13. REF: for example , it becomes possible to conduct detailed accounting of the expenditure of funds on the social card down to the last kopeck .

    HYP: thus , there is a possibility to conduct a detailed account of expenditure of money on social card with accuracy up to kopecks .


  14. REF: moreover , it becomes possible to refund loaded but unspent funds .

    HYP: moreover , there is a possibility of returning the numerical but unspent money .


  15. REF: it 's also worth noting that the system of mutual settlements with carriers will become transparent , since a citizen now pays for half of the fare , and the carrier will be reimbursed in the exact same amount from the budget .

    HYP: we also add that a scheme of mutual settlements with carriers becomes transparent as now half of the fare is paid by the citizen , and exactly the same amount will be reimbursed to the carrier of the budget .


  16. REF: no commission fee will be charged for loading funds onto the card .

    HYP: no commission will be charged for a cash deposit .


  17. REF: in turn , Vasily Silkin , Deputy Head of the Department of Public Roads and Transportation for Ivanovo region , reported that more than 33 million trips had been made using the social card in 2014 , and , in 2015 , almost 25 million trips .

    HYP: in turn , Vasily Silkin , deputy head of the Department of Road and Transport of the Ivanovo Region , reported that in 2014 , there were more than 33 million journeys using the social card , in 2015-16 - nearly 25 million journeys .

    HYP: there are more than 470 million rubles to provide preferential accommodation for citizens with the use of the social card .


  19. REF: as of September 1 , the total spent for this purpose amounted to more than 312 million roubles .

    HYP: as of September 1 , the amount of reimbursement for these purposes amounted to more than 312 million rubles .

    HYP: you can send us your photos and videos or send an SMS to the number 61124 .

    HYP: if you are outside the UK , send messages to +44 7624 800 100 .

    HYP: send your stories and comments to haveyoursay @ bbc.co.uk

    HYP: send us your images , videos or audio to yourpics @ bbc.co.uk

    HYP: the rate of growth has been the highest since 2009 , and has been met as a transfer to earlier forecasts for potential growth of quotations .

    HYP: Metcash is trying to protect its IGA stores from an Aldi lawsuit in South Australia and Western Australia .

  292. REF: as Aldi prepares to open two distribution centres and the first of as many as 120 stores in South Australia and Western Australia early next year , Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening relationships with local food suppliers and building the IGA brand through mainstream and social media marketing and events such as the Adelaide show .

    HYP: the campaigns are being joined by retailers and IGA suppliers , such as the ice cream maker Simmo 's of Dansborough , which offers tasting at the IGA stores , and shop owners selling off the discount to regular customers tickets to the South Australia Football League matches .

    HYP: Metcash is expected to reveal more details of its defense strategy on September 29 - a day when this wholesale supplier of food , liquor and household goods will spend its annual day investor strategies .


  295. REF: there is much at stake , as South Australia and Western Australia account for almost 30 per cent of Metcash 's IGA store footprint and generate higher profit margins than Metcash 's IGA network in the eastern states .

    HYP: there is a lot at stake , since in South Australia and Western Australia stores under the brand IGA make up almost 30 per cent of all Metcash stores and show higher profitability than the Metcash IGA network in eastern states .


  296. REF: South Australian and Western Australian shoppers are notoriously parochial and IGA retailers enjoy a much stronger market share than they do in NSW , Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in SA and 24 per cent in WA compared with around 14 per cent in the Eastern states .

    HYP: buyers in South and Western Australia are known as adherents of the usual routes , so the market here is more favorable for the IGA retailers than in the states of New South Wales , Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in Utah and 24 per cent in WA compared to about 14 percent in eastern states .


  297. REF: however , analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe Aldi will snare around 5 per cent of the grocery market in these two states within 12 months of opening its first stores , taking sales from all existing players but mainly from independent retailers .

    HYP: however , analysts like Morgan Stanley believe Aldi will roll out 5 percent of the food market in these two states within 12 months of opening its first stores , picking up sales at all present players , but mainly by independent retailers .


  298. REF: in a report this week , Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath estimated that IGA retailers could lose $ 360 million a year in sales and Metcash $ 250 million by the end of 2016 .

    HYP: in a report this week , Tom Cirat , an analyst at Morgan Stanley , said IGA retailers could lose $ 360 million in sales for the year , and Metcash - $ 250 million by the end of 2016 .


  299. REF: this forecast is based on the assumption that Aldi opens 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA next year , generating sales of $ 500 million and $ 600 million in each market .

    HYP: the forecast is based on assumptions that Aldi next year will open 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA , producing sales of 500 million and $ 600 million in these markets respectively .


  300. REF: the loss of food and grocery sales and volumes on Metcash 's high fixed-cost base could cost Metcash around $ 13 million in earnings before interest and tax , Mr Kierath said .

    HYP: Metcash 's loss of revenue and sales volumes at a high level of constant costs could cost the company about 13 million of revenues before interest and taxes , Mr Kirat said .


  301. REF: at the same time , Metcash is losing market share in the eastern states , mainly to Aldi and Coles , even though a recent Roy Morgan survey found IGA shoppers were most loyal .

    HYP: at the same time , Metcash loses market share in the eastern states , mainly because of Aldi and Coles , and that 's when a recent study by Morgan Survey found that IGA had the most loyal buyers .


  302. REF: Morgan Stanley believes Metcash 's food and grocery sales will fall 3.8 per cent in 2016 , 4.1 per cent in 2017 and 2.1 per cent in 2018 , reducing its market share from 14 per cent in 2015 to 10.3 per cent by 2020 .

    HYP: at Morgan Stanley , Metcash sales will fall 3.8 per cent in 2016 , up 4.1 per cent in 2017 and 2.1 per cent in 2018 , reducing the company 's stake in the market from 14 per cent in 2015 to 10.3 per cent by 2020 .

    HYP: last week 's leading stock manager , Heather Douglas , founder of Magellan Financial Group , spotted the present at a business dinner in Melbourne that Metcash `` could have a high probability of disappear over the course of a decade .

    HYP: Metcash declined to publicly comment on Mr Douglas 's comments .


  305. REF: but it is understood that a Metcash board member contacted Mr Douglass last week .

    HYP: but it is alleged that a member of the Board of Directors of Metcash contacted Mr Douglas last week .


  306. REF: IGA 's market share has fallen from 18 per cent to 14 per cent since 2010 and earnings from Metcash 's food and grocery business , which supplies about 1200 IGA retailers , have fallen 43 per cent since 2012 , reflecting operating deleverage as sales and margins come under pressure .

    HYP: the share of IGA on the market has declined since 2010 from 18 to 14 percent , and Metcash 's revenues from business in the food sector , which the company supplies around 1200 IGA retailers , fell 43 percent compared to 2012 due to operational deleverage , and due to pressure on sales and profitability .


  307. REF: however , the wholesaler is fighting back , investing more than $ 150 million a year matching shelf prices at Coles and Woolworths on hundreds of products each week , helping IGA retailers refurbish stores by adding faster-growing fresh food , and rolling out a better range of private label groceries .

    HYP: however , the company does not end up spending more than $ 150 million annually for equalising retail prices with the prices of Coles and Woolworths on a thousand-mile weekly and helping the IGA retailers in the rearrangement of trading platforms , as well as offering a rapidly expanding product range and a wider selection of branded food .

    HYP: Metcash CEO Ian Morris says the price tag and re-equipment of shopping areas is gaining momentum and hopes the company will succeed in increasing net profit in 2017 , for the first time in four years .

  324. REF: Europe migrant crisis : Hungary declares emergency , seals border , detains migrants

    HYP: migrant crisis in Europe : Hungary declares emergency , closes border , detains migrants


  325. REF: declaring a state of emergency , Hungary sealed off its southern border with Serbia on Tuesday and detained those trying to enter illegally , aiming to shut down the flow of migrants pouring in .

    HYP: by announcing an emergency , Hungary on Tuesday shut down the border with Serbia on the southern border and deters those trying to penetrate the country illegally to stem the flow of migrants .


  326. REF: chaos ensued at the border , as hundreds of migrants piled up in a no man 's land , and Serbian officials reacted with outrage .

    HYP: on the border there were unrest - hundreds of migrants were buried on the border area , which the Serbian authorities reacted sharply .


  327. REF: stuck for an unknown amount of time on a strip of road between the two countries ' checkpoints , those fleeing violence in their homelands pitched tents and settled in .

    HYP: stuck on an indefinite time on the road between the checkpoints of two countries , people fleeing armed violence at home have broken up tents and grounded out on this terrain .


  328. REF: but frustrations were on the rise .

    HYP: however , the discontent was mounting .


  329. REF: as a police helicopter hovered above , migrants chanted `` Open the border ! '' and shouted insults at Hungarian riot police .

    HYP: when the police helicopter circled them over them , migrants shouted `` Down the border ! '' and shouted insults at the Hungarian police special .


  330. REF: some refused food and water in protest .

    HYP: some in protest refused food and water .

    HYP: Serbia wants to be part of a solution to the problem , not collateral damage .

    HYP: it is necessary to hold negotiations with Brussels and other countries in the coming days , '' said Ivica Dachich in Prague .

    HYP: the unrest at the Hungarian border began the day after a bloc of 28 countries failed to develop a general immigration policy at a joint meeting in Brussels .


  335.     HYP: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria on Tuesday demanded to gather next week an emergency EU summit to discuss the immigration crisis engulfing the continent .


  337. REF: Hungary , however , was not pinning its hopes on any action soon from Brussels or its neighbors .

    HYP: Hungary , however , does not hope for swift action by Brussels or its neighbors .


  338. REF: Tuesday 's state of emergency in two southern regions gave authorities greater powers to deal with the crisis , allowing them to shut down roads and speed up asylum court cases .

    HYP: declared on Tuesday a state of emergency in two southern regions gave authorities more powers to action against the crisis , allowing them to overturn the roads and speed up court cases for asylum .


  339. REF: meanwhile , Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said his country is also planning to build a razor-wire fence along part of its border with Romania to stop the flow of migrants through the country , now that it has finished a fence on the Serbian border .

    HYP: meanwhile , Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Sijbright said his country was planning also to take a fence from a barbed wire fence along the border with Romania to shut down the flow of migrants through the country , now that it has finished a fence on the Serbian border .


  340. REF: CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prison inmates were enlisted in the race to finish the razor wire fence between Hungary and Serbia .

    HYP: CBS News correspondent Charlie Dagata said even prisoners were connected to urgent work on completion of a fence between Hungary and Serbia .


  341. REF: in the last few months , Hungary has become a major bottleneck and entry point into the European Union for migrants , many of them war refugees from Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East .

    HYP: over the past few months , Hungary has been a major `` bottleneck '' and a point of crossing the EU 's borders for migrants , many of whom are refugees - the victims of the wars in Syria and the Middle East .


  342. REF: Prime Minister Viktor Orban , however , has insisted that most arriving are economic migrants seeking a better life , not war refugees entitled to protection - a view sharply at odds with other EU nations , including Germany .

    HYP: however , Prime Minister Viktor Orban insists that most arrivals in the country are economic migrants , seeking more welfare and not refugees - the victims of military action , which are entitled to protection , and this view will sharply diverge from the views of other EU countries , including Germany .


  343. REF: the new laws that took effect at midnight in Hungary now make it a crime to cross or damage a 4-meter ( 13-foot ) razor-wire fence the government has built along the southern border with Serbia and also includes longer prison terms for convicted human traffickers .

    HYP: the new laws , which joined Hungary into force at midnight , are thought to be now a crime of crossing or damage to a 4-metre ( 13-foot ) fence from a barbed wire built by the government along the southern border with Serbia , and includes longer jail terms for the accused in human trafficking .


  344. REF: `` Due to the situation caused by mass migration , the Hungarian government declares a state of crisis , '' government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters in the southern city of Szeged .

    HYP: `` Because of the situation caused by mass migration , the Hungarian government declares a state of emergency , '' government spokesman Zoltan Kovach said in the southern city of Seged .


  345. REF: we are very clear on this : illegal border crossing is a crime .

    HYP: we are clearly giving it clear : illegal crossing of the border is a crime .


  346. REF: technically , parliament must still approve the deployment of the military , expected next week , but Associated Press reporters at the border have seen heavily armed military personnel with vehicles and dogs for days .

    HYP: formally parliament still has to sanction the deployment of military forces , which is expected next week , but the Associated Press reporters who are on the border for several days are watching the presence of armed to the teeth of servicemen with vehicles and dogs .


  347. REF: Gyorgy Bakondi , homeland security adviser to Orban , said authorities caught 45 people trying to cross at the border and 15 deeper in the country .

    HYP: Dern Bakondi , an adviser to the National Security Agency , reported to the authorized bodies of 45 people attempting to cross the border , at the border , and another 15 people inside the country .


  348. REF: they got across by damaging the fence , are now in police custody and are being charged with committing offenses under the new laws .

    HYP: they have crossed the border , having broken the fence , are currently under police guard and are accused of carrying out administrative violations under new laws .


  349. REF: authorities are quickly repairing the fence .

    HYP: authorities are quick to recover the fence .


  350. REF: Hungarian officials also closed two of seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning after deploying a train car covered with razor wire to close one of them .

    HYP: Hungarian authorities on Tuesday morning also closed two of the seven passes along the border with Serbia , fit to block one of the aisles of a rail car , winding up a barbed wire .


  351. REF: chaos enveloped the main border crossing near Roszke , Hungary , as the Hungarians opened a tiny office in a metal container to process people and crowds pressed to squeeze inside .

    HYP: the unrest broke out at the main pro-crossing across the border near the town of Raleosk ( Hungary ) , as Hungarians posted an emergency room to pass people inside a metal container , and crowds pressed each other to break inside .


  352. REF: about 20 managed to get in , but thousands remained outside .

    HYP: the passage inside was managed by about 20 persons , with thousands of people being left outside .

    HYP: another group of migrants blocked the main road from Serbia to Hungary and refused food and water until they were missed in Hungary .

    HYP: Clinton supporters are more confident than supporting other candidates .

    HYP: Clinton holds a big advantage among women and moderates , but that advantage has dwindled .

    HYP: its support among men has substantially fallen and Sanders is lagging behind it by just 5 points .


  363. REF: Clinton 's advantage with Democratic voters under age 50 has evaporated , and she and Sanders are now even .

    HYP: the preference given to Clinton by the Democrats for up to 50 years is gone , and they are with Sanders now on equal footing .

    HYP: however , Clinton still has a big advantage among more senior voters .


  365. REF: last month , Clinton was ahead of Sanders by double-digits among liberals , but Sanders now has a 5-point edge with this group .

    HYP: last month , Clinton trailed Sanderes by a double-digit percentage among the Liberals , but Sanders now has an edge in five points in that group .

    HYP: nearly half of Democrats across the country said they would enthusiastically support Clinton if she became a candidate for the party .

    HYP: a quarter would have supported her with some reservations , and a further 15 percent would support her only because she 's a candidate .


  368. REF: six percent would not support her .

    HYP: six per cent would not support her .

    HYP: perhaps unsurprisingly , Clinton 's current supporters are likely to show more enthusiasm for her account .

    HYP: among those at the moment do not support Clinton , the view is more controversial - only about a quarter enthusiastically backing it .

    HYP: while 48 percent of Democratic primary voters say they would enthusiastically support Clinton , the smaller number of Republican presidential candidates say the same about their lead , Donald Trump ( 35 percent ) .


  372.     HYP: it is also called agreed not on the issues and odds of electing .

    HYP: among Clinton supporters more than half say they would have chosen Biden a second , that 's more than Sanders did .

  431. REF: here 's what will happen when the Fed raises interest rates

    HYP: what happens when the Federal Reserve raises interest rates


  432. REF: a rate hike will come and the bull market will stumble , bond yields will climb and the economy will slip into a recession .

    HYP: there will be a rate hike , and `` the bull market '' is stumbling , bond yields will rise , and the economy falls into recession .


  433. REF: this we know .

    HYP: that we know .


  434. REF: what we do n't know is how long all of that will take and how long it will last .

    HYP: what we do n't know is how long it will take until this time , and how long that will last .


  435. REF: for the economy specifically , history offers little guide about timing .

    HYP: specific to the economy , history shows little about time .


  436. REF: a recession has come as quickly as 11 months after the first rate hike and as long as 86 months .

    HYP: the recession came just 11 months after the first rate hike and for the whole 86 months .


  437. REF: the Federal Reserve 's aggressiveness in raising rates is often , though not always , a determinant in how the economy and financial assets respond .

    HYP: the rigidity of the Federal Reserve in raising rates often , though not always , determines the reaction of the economy and financial assets .


  438. REF: that 's why officials at the U.S. central bank have stressed so vigorously that investors should not be focused on when it starts raising rates but rather the trajectory of how long it will take to normalize .

    HYP: that is why the administration of the US Central Bank has so insistently emphasised that investors should not focus on when it starts to raise rates , but on how much adjustment will take .


  439. REF: there are , indeed , multiple variables at play .

    HYP: indeed , there are many variables in the game .


  440. REF: in the end , however , market participants may find that all the rate-hike fuss may have been overdone .

    HYP: after all , however , market participants may find that all fuss around raising rates is exaggerated .


  441. REF: `` The first hike from the Fed since the global financial crisis will inevitably be interpreted by some as signaling the end of the era of 'cheap money , ' `` Julian Jessop , chief global economist at Capital Economics , said in a note to clients .

    HYP: `` The first increase in rates by the Federal Reserve with the onset of the global financial crisis will inevitably be interpreted by some as the signal of the end of an era of `` cheap money , '' '' said Julian Jessop , chief specialist at the international economy at Capital Economics , in a statement to clients .


  442. REF: in contrast , we do not expect the gradual return of U.S. interest rates to more normal but still low levels to be the seismic shock that many seem to fear .

    HYP: on the contrary , we do not expect the gradual return of US interest rates to more normal , but still low levels will be a seismic impulse that many fear .


  443. REF: that 's not to say there wo n't be effects , however .

    HYP: that does not mean , however , that the consequences will not .


  444. REF: here 's a look at how some areas of the economy could react , based on historical trends :

    HYP: here 's a look at how some areas of the economy might react , depending on historical trends :


  445. REF: as the market has seen over the past month or so , anticipation of rate hikes can make things volatile for a while .

    HYP: as the market has seen over the last month or so , waiting for a rate hike could lead to instability for a while .


  446. REF: once the hike hits , though , the impact is not as dramatic .

    HYP: when raising rates , however , the consequences are usually not that dramatic .


  447. REF: `` It does seem there is a trend for equity returns to stall 12-24 months after the first hike , which again perhaps reflects the lag in monetary policy , '' Deutsche Bank analysts said in a recent study of what happens after the Fed hikes .

    HYP: `` It does not seem that the proceeds of the shares are based on 12-24 months after the first jump , which , again , probably reflects the delay in monetary policy , '' Deutsche Bank analysts said in a recent survey of the results of the Federal Reserve rate hikes .


  448. REF: more specifically , the market over the past 35 years or so is most often up sharply - about 14 percent - heading into the rate hike , fairly flat in the 250 days after ( average gain of 2.6 percent ) then back to normal once 500 days have passed , with average return in the past six cycles of 14.4 percent , according to a recent analysis Bob Doll , chief equity strategist at Nuveen Asset Management , posted on Barron 's .

    HYP: if more concretely , the market for the last roughly 35 years is more likely to change sharply - about 14 percent - in the direction of rate hikes - remains fairly flat for 250 days after that ( average growth of 2.6 percent ) , then , at the rate of 500 days , returns to a normal state with an average yield of 14.4 percent over the last six cycles , according to a recent analysis conducted by Bob Long , a principal trading analyst at Nuveen Asset Management , published in Barron 's .


  449. REF: Deutsche said the impact on stocks tends to get more pronounced later in the rate-hiking cycle and returns begin to diminish .

    HYP: Deutsche said that the result for securities tends not to be more pronounced at the rate of rate hikes , and earnings from stocks are beginning to decline .


  450. REF: recessions are a fact of economic life , but rate hikes often help them along .

    HYP: recessions are a fact of economic life , but raising rates often play by them .


  451. REF: in the current case , the Fed is facing some conditions that did not exist before and could hasten a recession .

    HYP: in this case , the Federal Reserve is placed under conditions that have not existed before and can precipitate recession .


  452. REF: most notably , gross domestic product will be near its lowest point ever for a Fed rate hike .

    HYP: basically , gross domestic product will be almost at its lowest point in the lifetime of an increased rate .


  453. REF: according to Deutsche Bank , in the 118 rate hikes since 1950 , only twice has nominal year over year GDP been below 4.5 percent .

    HYP: according to Deutsche Bank , in 118 cases of the rate increase since 1950 only twice nominal annual GDP was below 4.5 % .


  454. REF: even though the second quarter of 2015 was at 3.6 percent , few expect that to last , with the third quarter tracking at just 1.5 percent , according to the Atlanta Fed .

    HYP: even though in the second quarter of 2015 , it was 3.6 percent , few believe that this is for a long time when it holds only 1.5 per cent in the third quarter , according to the Atlanta Fed .


  455. REF: hiking rates into such a fragile economic backdrop could be risky and set up the question of `` whether this time is different , '' Deutsche said .

    HYP: raising rates on such an unstable economic background can be risky and raises the question `` will this time differently , '' reported Deutsche .


  456. REF: market participants have been bracing for a Fed hike all year , with all eyes turned toward this week 's Federal Open Market Committee meeting , which ends Thursday .

    HYP: market participants are preparing to raise rates for the Federal Reserve all year round , with their view drawn up by the Federal Open Market Committee , which ends Thursday .


  457. REF: while many strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve a hike at this meeting , futures trading indicates just a 25 percent probability .

    HYP: as long as many experts on strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve a rate hike at this meeting , the futures trade speaks only about a 25-cent probability .


  458. REF: `` In our study since 1950 , all hiking cycles to date have been in a super cycle of increasing leverage with GDP eclipsing prerecession peaks very quickly post the recovery commencing , '' the report said .

    HYP: `` In our study , since 1950 , all the cycles of rate hikes before today were in the supercycle of an increased fiscal lever under GDP , overlapping of the peaks before recession , very quickly after recovery , '' the report said .


  459. REF: by contrast this has been a uniquely slow recovery from what was the worst recession in the sample period .

    HYP: by contrast , it was an extremely slow recovery after the worst recession in the chosen period .


  460. REF: the current cycle is by far the longest the Fed has waited since the end of the last recession ; the record had been 35 months , and this is 74 months and counting .

    HYP: the current cycle at the moment - the longest that the Federal Reserve has been waiting for since the end of the last recession ; the record was 35 months ; it only lasts for 74 months and is not over yet .


  461. REF: fixed income also has been volatile as the market anticipates a rate hike , and the pattern is somewhat similar to what equities experience .

    HYP: fixed income has also become volatile while the market is expecting a rate hike , and this scenario is somewhat like the one that is being implemented for the shares .


  462. REF: the principal difference is that the impact happens faster in bonds than stocks when the Fed changes course in policy .

    HYP: the principal difference is that there will be an effect in the bonds than for shares when the Federal system changes its strategic course .


  463. REF: for bonds , it does seem yields change direction immediately as the first hike/cut in the cycle arrives .

    HYP: in the case of bonds , it seems that yields change the vector immediately after the first increase / reduction of rates in the cycle .


  464. REF: at the end of the hiking cycle bond yields fall immediately , '' Deutsche said .

    HYP: at the end of the cycle of rising rates , bond yields are immediately falling , '' Deutsche said .


  465. REF: Charles Schwab strategists believe the hike in rates will cause yields between longer- and shorter-dated bonds to move closer together , flattening the curve .

    HYP: strategy specialists from Charles Schwab believe a rate rise will result in the rates of long-term and short-term bond yields close , making the curve more flat .


  466. REF: high-yield bonds often perform better in such a climate , though `` we are still cautious about stretching for yield , '' Kathy Jones , fixed income analyst at Schwab , said in an analysis .

    HYP: high-yield bonds often behave better in such a climate , although `` we still fear fluctuations in returns , '' according to the study of Kathy Jones , a fixed-income analyst in Schwab .


  467. REF: interestingly , Jones thinks markets already have adapted to Fed policy expectations .

    HYP: interestingly , Jones believes markets have already adapted to the expected outcome of Fed policy .


  468. REF: `` In addition to the strength in the dollar and the drop in inflation expectations , there are several signs that the market has adjusted to the prospect of tighter monetary policy , '' she wrote .

    HYP: `` In addition to strengthening the dollar and falling inflation expectations there are signs that the market has been rigged towards the prospect of tighter monetary policy , '' she wrote .


  469. REF: short-term interest rates are up , the yield curve is flatter , credit spreads have widened and volatility has increased - all characteristics of the market when the Fed tightens policy .

    HYP: interest rates on short-term loans have risen , the yield curve is more flat , the credit spreads have expanded , volatility has increased - all characteristics of the market in tightening the policy of the Federal System .


  470. REF: broadly speaking , companies that do the majority of their business in the U.S. will win as interest rates rise and local products become more attractive .

    HYP: speaking in general , companies leading the core of their business in the US will benefit from rising interest rates , and local production will become more attractive .


  471. REF: multinationals with lots of debt will fare worse , as a rising dollar makes their products more expensive in the global market space and their debt more expensive the finance .

    HYP: international companies with many debts will be worse off as the rising dollar makes their products more expensive in the global marketplace , and their debt more expensive - financially .


  472. REF: `` History shows that 'quality ' stocks tend to outperform during the three months following an initial rate hike , '' Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report for clients .

    HYP: `` History shows that `` quality '' shares demonstrate efficiencies above the market in the three months after the initial rate hike , '' said Goldman Sachs ' analysts in a report for customers .


  473. REF: firms with strong balance sheets outpaced weak balance sheet companies following each of the 1994 , 1999 , and 2004 rate hikes , by an average of 5 percentage points .

    HYP: companies with a stable financial condition cost the company an unstable condition on the results of each rate increase in 1994 , 1999 and 2004 , at an average of 5 percentage points .

    HYP: companies with high capital ratios and stocks with low volatility also showed better performance than low-quality stocks , averaging 4 ( percentage points ) and 3 ( percentage points ) respectively .

    HYP: debt will be a big issue .

    HYP: companies with a high percentage of floating rate debt will lose the most , according to Goldman .

    HYP: aside from purely exchange-traded deals , consumers will benefit from the rising dollar .

    HYP: depositors could see profit also through higher returns , though experts diverge in how quickly this will happen .

  617. REF: it is no coincidence that in all the other countries where rescue programmes were in effect or continue to operate , political forces and all the ruling parties got together in order to implement the programme that they had reached a consensus on , while , at the same time , never abandoning their political or ideological independence .

    HYP: and it is no accident that in all other countries where there were or still bailout programs , political forces and all ruling parties were put together to implement a program on which they reached consent without relinquishing their political or ideological autonomy .


  618. REF: that 's why I firmly believe that , at this stage , only the cooperation of political forces and institutes will enable the country to move forward .

    HYP: that is why I firmly believe that , at the present stage , only the cooperation of political forces and institutions will allow the country to go ahead .

    HYP: euronews : your party voted in support of an agreement between Mr Tsipras and the country 's creditors .

    HYP: Vangelis Maymarakis : in fact we voted for Greece 's movement on the European way , because it is well presented that the disastrous consequences would lead the country 's exit from the EU .

    HYP: I know that Europe is unwilling to destroy us .

    HYP: Europe wants to help us .


  627.     HYP: so if Europe sees that the new Greek government in the first year in power wants to impose order , act rationally , and makes clear that the country has a strong political will to implement the bailout program , then , I am sure , all the accepted commitments that can not be met because of the recession may be negotiated again , but only after a certain time .

    HYP: but some researchers questioned the authenticity of the data and pointed to the association of some experts with the tobacco industry .

    HYP: in an editorial in the medical journal Lancet last month split `` an extremely shaky argument '' on the basis of which PHE built its main conclusion .


  836. REF: writing in the BMJ , two further researchers have questioned whether the claims were `` built on rock or sand . ''

    HYP: in the BMJ article , two other researchers wondered whether these claims were `` solid or firm grounds . ''


  837. ''

    HYP: Martin McKee , a lecturer at the European Health Institute at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine , and Simon Klingwell , lecturer in clinical epidemiology at Leeds University , reported : `` A fundamental principle of health care should be based on proof of efficiency . ''


  838. REF: they said the public would expect PHE 's claims that `` the current best estimate is that e-cigarettes are around 95 % less harmful than smoking '' would be based on a detailed review of evidence and modelling .

    HYP: according to them , the public expects the PHE claims that `` the current best estimate shows that e-cigarettes are about 95 % less harmful than tabacocration '' was based on a detailed breakdown of evidence and modelling .


  839. REF: in fact , it comes from a single meeting of 12 people convened to develop a multi-criteria decision analysis ( MCDA ) model to synthesise their opinions on the harms associated with different nicotine-containing products ; the results of the meeting were summarised in a research paper .

    HYP: in fact , it is derived from the only meeting of the 12 people assembled for the development of a multicrito analysis model of decision making in order to summarize their opinions about the harm associated with the various nicotine products ; the results of the meeting are summarized in scientific publication .


  840. REF: McKee and Capewell said one sponsor of the meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health , whose chief executive was reported to have previously received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study .

    HYP: Makki and Kepwell reported that one of the sponsors of the meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health , a general directive reported that he had previously received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study .


  841. REF: he also endorsed BAT 's public health credentials in a sustainability report , they said .

    HYP: he also confirmed BAT certificates in the health care report on sustainable development .


  842. REF: one of the 12 people at the meeting declared funding from an e-cigarette manufacturer but not the funding he was reported to have received previously from the tobacco company Philip Morris International , they added .

    HYP: one in 12 people at the meeting announced a funding from the e-cigarette maker , without mentioning the funding it reportedly had previously received from Philip Morris 's tobacco company .


  843. REF: the rationale for selecting the members of the panel is not provided , but they include several known e-cigarette champions , some of whom also declare industry funding in the paper .

    HYP: a reasonable explanation for the choice of council members was not available , but among them there are some prominent supporters of e-cigarettes , some of whom have also claimed to fund the industry in publication .


  844. REF: some others present at the meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control .

    HYP: it is not known if there were other participants in the management experience in the tobacco case .


  845. REF: the meeting was also attended by the tobacco lead at PHE .

    HYP: the meeting was also visited by the head of the tobacco business in PHE .


  846. REF: the research paper produced by the group `` tellingly concedes '' there is a lack of `` hard evidence for the harms of most products on most of the criteria , '' McKee and Capewell wrote .

    HYP: the scientific paper , published by the group , is `` graceful agrees '' that there is a lack of `` weight evidence of the harmful impact of most products on the majority of the criteria , '' wrote Mck and Keewell .


  847. REF: however , none of these links or limitations are discussed in the PHE report .

    HYP: however , none of these links and limitations have been affected in the PHE report .

    HYP: Makky and Keewell told PHE that PHE claims that `` at present there is no evidence that e-cigarettes are expensive , resulting in children or non-smokers to smoke , '' are premature .

    HYP: Prof. Kevin Fenton , head of health and welfare in PHE , said that BMJ 's statements had previously been given the answers .


  850. REF: he said : `` E-cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking . ''

    HYP: he said : `` e-cigarettes are substantially less harmful than tobacco . ''


  851. REF: one in two lifelong smokers dies from their addiction .

    HYP: one of the two chickens died of his addiction .


  852. REF: all of the evidence suggests that the health risks posed by e-cigarettes are small by comparison , but we must continue to study the long-term effects .

    HYP: all evidence implies that the dangers of health from e-cigarettes are relatively low , but we must continue to study remote consequences .

    HYP: the PHE has a clear duty to inform the public about what to prove and what these evidence proves , especially where there were doubts about the relative danger in tobacco .


  854. REF: nearly 80,000 people a year die of a smoking-related illness and smoking costs the NHS £2bn a year .

    HYP: about 80,000 people a year die from smoking disease and smoking is costing the NHS £2 billion a year .

    HYP: it is clear that although e-cigarettes are not safe , they only do part of the damage done by smoking - we do our tasks in front of the nation .

    HYP: Johnson noticed that licensing fees should be used only to create programs that are not produced by other British TV and Radio companies .

    HYP: after BBC director-general Tony Hall said the corporation wanted more cooperation with other organisations , Johnson noticed that he had in his time spent six years unsuccessfully trying to establish a collaboration with the BBC while working on Channel 4 .

    HYP: if you save a license fee that I do not consider a good solution in the medium and long term , then companies should be left with only those programs that are not produced and are not collected by other companies .

    HYP: the Voice shows the broadcast in prime-time , because the creators want to gain as much support as possible for the future .

    HYP: the idea that nobody will show it is laughable and apparently absurd .

    HYP: Johnson : `` I do n't understand why regressive taxes should go on funding passes that could be sponsored without subsidies .

    HYP: the Voice is one such example , EastEnders is another ; it is generally known that they own production .


  867. REF: frankly other channels would give their right arm for it .

    HYP: there were no other channels , no doubt a lot would be given to her .

    HYP: I do n't understand how this can be a public thing .

    HYP: I do n't think it would somehow embrace the BBC .

  879. REF: 'Sonogenetics ' allows brain cells to be controlled by sound waves

    HYP: 'Sonogenetic ' allows brain cells to be controlled using sound waves


  880. REF: the video shows how the nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses .

    HYP: on the video you can see how the nematodes change direction of movement at the moment when they are exposed to sound impulses .


  881. REF: scientists have bred worms with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves .

    HYP: scientists have led the worms with a genetically modified nervous system , which can be controlled using the sound wavelengths of the sound waves .


  882. REF: the tiny nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses that are too high-pitched for humans to hear .

    HYP: tiny nematodes change direction of movement at the moment when they are affected by sound impulses , too high so that the human ear can hear them .


  883. REF: the pulses work by switching on motor neuron cells that are genetically modified to carry membrane channels that respond to ultrasonic waves .

    HYP: impulses have an impact by activating neurons , genetically modified , to use membrane channels that respond to ultrasound waves .


  884. REF: related : researchers read and write brain activity with light

    HYP: still on the subject : researchers run brain activity by light


  885. REF: researchers said the worms demonstrate the power of a new procedure , dubbed sonogenetics , in which ultrasound can be used to activate a range of brain , heart and muscle cells from outside the body .

    HYP: scientists have told that the worms demonstrate the possibility of a new method called `` sonogenetic , '' whose essence is the use of ultrasound for the excitation of certain brain cells , heart and muscle , and the source of ultrasound is located outside of the body .


  886. REF: Sreekanth Chalasani , a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla , California , told the Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep-brain stimulation , an invasive procedure that delivers electrical pulses into people 's brains to treat symptoms of Parkinson 's disease .

    HYP: Srikant Chalasani , a researcher at the Solka Institute , La Hoya , California , told the Guardian that this technique could one day replace deep brain stimulation - an invasive procedure whereby a person 's brain is sent by electrical impulses and which is used in the treatment of Parkinson 's disease .


  887. REF: nematode worms do not usually react to ultrasound , but Chalasani found that they did when they were surrounded by a fluid containing microscopic bubbles .

    HYP: the nematodes usually do not react to ultrasound , but Chalasani found that they started to react when they were placed in a fluid containing microscopic bubbles .


  888. REF: the bubbles , he found , amplify the ultrasonic waves which then pass inside the worms .

    HYP: he found that the bubbles increase the ultrasound waves , which then penetrate the worms .


  889. REF: the amplified ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels , found in the membranes of some of the worms '' cells .

    HYP: the amplified ultrasonic waves affect the structures called `` ion channels of TRP-4 , '' found in the membranes of some of the worms .


  890. REF: the sound waves make these ion channels open up and activate the cells they are attached to , according to a report in Nature Communications .

    HYP: ultrasound waves make these ion channels open and excited the cells that are dealt with are reported in the report in Nature Communications .


  891. REF: to make ultrasound-controlled nematodes , Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carried TRP-4 ion channels .

    HYP: for the creation of nematode , which can be controlled by ultrasound , Chalasani made genetic modifications of worms so that their motor neurons used TRP-4 channel channels .


  892. REF: when he applied ultrasound to the modified creatures , the sound waves were amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted into the worms , where they switched on the modified motor neurons .

    HYP: during ultrasound to influence modified organisms , sound waves amplified microscopic bubbles and injected into the organisms of worms , activating modified motor neurons .


  893. REF: the procedure has some similarities with optogenetics , a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to switch neurons on and off with pulses of light .

    HYP: this technique is similar to those used in `` optogenetics '' - a new direction that allows scientists to include and turn off neurons using light pulses .


  894. REF: but Chalasani said that sonogenetics could have some advantages over that technique .

    HYP: Chalasani argues that , compared to this methodology , sonogenetic may have some benefits .


  895. REF: unlike light , which has to be sent down an optic fibre to the desired location inside the brain , low frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue unhindered , and so can be sent into the brain from on top of the skull .

    HYP: in contrast to the light which is delivered to the desired part of the brain on fiber optic , low-frequency ultrasonic waves can flow freely through the tissues of the organism , so it is not necessary for their delivery to go inside the shingle box .


  896. REF: `` We believe that , using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus , it may be possible to make target human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments , '' said Chalasani .

    HYP: `` We believe that in order to treat certain neurological diseases in clinical conditions , the use of gene therapy and therapeutic viruses will be able to take time to make human neurons sensitive to an ultrasound signal , '' Mr Chalasani said .


  897. REF: other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells , he added .

    HYP: he added that , in addition , the technique can be applied to muscle and insulin producing cells .


  898. REF: illegal torture equipment - right on your doorstep !

    HYP: the banned vacuum equipment - right on your doorstep !

    HYP: most likely he will offer you not to be shy , even if inside is boiling from rage .


  955. REF: if someone steals your stuff , it 's annoying and you have my sympathies - but try to deal with it more maturely than my hallmate , who tainted her milk with washing-up liquid to punish those who stole it .

    HYP: if someone forgets your things , it 's annoying , and I do n't feel like it - but try to get to this adult than my neighbor , who poured into my milk fluid for washing dishes to avenge those who took it without asking .


  956. REF: she 's in jail now .

    HYP: she is now in prison .


  957. REF: you should n't make noise that keeps people from sleeping or studying .

    HYP: you do n't have to produce a noise that 's going to discourage people from sleeping or learning .


  958. REF: this is n't just to be a decent human , but because you are the proverbial people in glass houses .

    HYP: not only to be a decent person , but also because you are the most people of the saying about glass at home .

    HYP: a girl in my corridor asked the neighbor to kill the sound of the drum and the bass guitar as it was 3 : 00 in the morning , and in the morning of the exam .


  960. REF: they responded by turning it up .

    HYP: in response , the neighbor increased the volume .


  961. REF: when they finally shut up at 5am , she kindly let them sleep for two hours before blasting her own music , locking her door as she left for her three-hour exam .

    HYP: when he stopped at 5 in the morning , she graciously allowed him to sleep for two hours and then rubbed his music and locked the door behind him for a three-hour examination .


  962. REF: would n't it be romantic if your future spouse happened to move into the same hall as you ?

    HYP: did n't romantically wonder if your future spouse had settled in the same hostel as you ?


  963. REF: conversely , would n't it be knuckle-bitingly awkward if you mistook a hallmate for your future spouse , hooked up , broke up and had to see them every day and possibly watch them get custody of all your mutual friends ?

    HYP: of course , the heart does n't show up - but if a hot neighbour is exactly not your future spouse , try to cool down your own dust .

    HYP: hints on the phone will allow you to go through the whole process until the end .

  995. REF: imported yachts will be exempt from paying customs duties .

    HYP: the imported yachts will be exempt from paying customs duties .

  999. REF: in June 2015 , as a result of a trip to Crimea , Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev instructed a number of government agencies - the Ministry of Economic Development , the Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation , the Ministry of Culture , the Ministry of Foreign Affairs , the Ministry of Emergency Situations , the Federal Security Service , the Federal Customs Service , and the Federal Tourism Agency - to prepare proposals to create favourable conditions for yachting in the costal regions of the country .

  1000. REF: in turn , experts point out that the main problem is the complete lack of infrastructure for storage , servicing , and maintenance of yachts .

    HYP: in turn , experts point out that the main problem is the complete lack of infrastructure for storage , maintenance and maintenance of the yachts .


  1001. REF: owners prefer to store their vessels abroad : approximately €200 mln every year enters the coffers of European states for the maintenance , repair , and servicing of yachts .

    HYP: owners prefer to keep their ships abroad - about €200 million each year go to European states for maintenance , repair and maintenance of yachts .


  1002.     HYP: the Russian Ministry of Economic Development prepared a draft of the decision of the Eurasian Economic Commission on Amendments to Perechen of Goods , temporarily imported with full conditional discharge from payment of customs duties , taxes , '' stipulating a full conditional discharge from payment of customs duties , taxes on imported yachts and other floating means for recreation and sports .


  1003. REF: according to the ministry , this would certainly support the creation of favourable conditions for the development of yachting in the coastal regions of the country , Lashkina noted .

  1006.   1007. REF: the list of imported goods that are fully exempt from payment of customs duties and taxes includes goods that are necessary for facilitating foreign trade and international cooperation , for use in the fields of science , culture , film , sport , and tourism , for the provision of international aid , and others . these other goods include : office equipment ( personal computers , typewriters ) , monitoring and measuring instruments , drilling equipment , stage costumes and sets , mobile laboratories and workshops , water skis , race cars , motorcycles , sport aircraft , books , newspapers , magazines , musical instruments , and items for religious ceremonies .

    HYP: the list of imported goods , which are completely exempt from customs duties , taxes , includes goods necessary to support foreign economic activities and international cooperation , for application in the sphere of science , culture , cinematography , sport and tourism , to provide international assistance and other facilities - service equipment ( personal computers , recording machines ) , control laboratories and workshops , water skiing , racing cars , motorcycles , sports flying devices , books , newspapers , magazines , music instruments and objects for religious ceremonies .


  1008.     HYP: prisons are asked to create separate blocks for transgender people .

    HYP: on the Public Council at the Federal Service of Punishment ( FSIN ) on the protection of the rights of convicts in October 2015 , among other issues will discuss the possibility of creating in columns of separate blocks for transgender and transvestites .


  1032. REF: a member of the council , Vladislav Grib , spoke to Izvestia about this .

    HYP: Vladislav Grib , a member of the Board , spoke about it .


  1033. REF: according to him , depending on the number of prisoners in Russia who are questioning their gender identity , it may be possible to provide separate cells or blocs in domestic prisons , or even ( if there are a lot of such criminals ) the establishment of a special penal colony for transsexuals in the future .

    HYP: in his opinion , depending on the total number of people in Russia who are not determined with sex , in domestic prisons it is possible to envisage individual cameras , blocs or even ( if such criminals are many ) at the prospect of creating a special colony for transsexuals .


  1034. REF: however , Vladislav Grib stresses that assigning a citizen to serve out a sentence in such isolated areas would only be possible after the convicted person had gone through the necessary medical examination that proves that the criminal is actually a person who identifies themselves as a member of the opposite sex .

    HYP: however , Vladislav Grib stresses that defining the punishment of citizens to such isolated places is possible only after the convicts will undergo appropriate medical expertise that will prove that the perpetrator is truly a person identifying themselves as a representative of the opposite sex .


  1035. REF: Vladislav Grib is sure that separating transgender people from other prisoners will ensure the safety of those serving out their sentences .

    HYP: Vladislav Grib is convinced that the isolation of transgender people from other prisoners will ensure the safety of the punishment .


  1036. REF: according to him , the proposed method is being successfully applied abroad : in a pre-trial detention facility ( where the accused stay until the court 's ruling ) , separate cells are made available for transgender people , and in correctional facilities there are special blocs .

    HYP: according to him , the offered practice successfully operates abroad : in the detention centre ( where the accused are before the court 's decision ) there are separate cameras for transgender people , and in correctional institutions - special units .


  1037. REF: currently , this is the only way of dealing with these types of criminals .

    HYP: today , this is the only way to work with such criminals .


  1038. REF: obviously , they need to be separated , as the presence of transvestites and transgender people in regular cells is dangerous for them : it causes suffering for their families and a sea of troubles for FSIN staff .

    HYP: unequivocally they need to isolate , because the presence of transvestites and transgender people in conventional chambers is dangerous for them , it is suffering for their families and a sea of problems for FSIN staff .


  1039. REF: the humiliation of trans people by their cellmates is guaranteed , says Vladislav Grib .

    HYP: the humiliation of the trenches by the co-cameras is guaranteed , '' says Vladislav Grib .


  1040. REF: it 's necessary to figure out where to place them , depending on how large of a city it is , and how many criminals there are that are questioning their gender identity .

    HYP: depending on how big a city is , how many criminals with undefined floors , it is necessary to count on where to distribute them .


  1041. REF: separate pre-trial detention facilities are n't necessary , just separate cells , and blocs in prisons .

    HYP: detention centres are not exactly needed - only cameras , prison blocks .


  1042. REF: yes , a separate penal colony is a possibility if there turn out to be many transgendered people .

    HYP: yes , a separate colony is possible if transgender people are much .


  1043. REF: as Grib explains , a bloc could hold 50 or 100 people , and if one specialised building is established in Russia , then convicted transsexuals from any region could be sent there to serve out their sentences .

    HYP: Grib explained that in the block can contain 50 or 100 people , and if a specialized body is created in Russia one , then punishment prisoners transsexual will be able from any regions .


  1044. REF: citizens are held in pre-trial detention facilities according to the place where the crime was committed , and , as such , the arrival of transvestites or transgender people from different territorial subjects during the investigation and court proceedings is unrealistic ; however , introducing this practice in a separate colony , for those who have already been convicted is definitely possible , Grib believes .

    HYP: citizens are kept in custody at the place of crime , so the receipt of transvestites or transgender persons from other subjects during the investigation and judicial process is unrealistic , and here is the practice for prisoners in a separate colony - yes , Grib believes .


  1045. REF: to recap , yesterday , law enforcement officers could not decide which pre-trial detention facility - male or female - to assign to 24-year-old transsexual Dmitry Kozhukov ( known as Alina Davis ) , detained for drug possession , and , as a result , the man with a girlish appearance was not arrested .

    HYP: it should be reminded , on the eve of the law enforcement bodies were unable to decide in which an investigating insulator - male or female - to determine the detainee for drug possession of 24-year-old transgender Dmitry Kozukova ( known under the name Alina Davis ) , because of which a man with a virgin appearance was not arrested .


  1046. REF: he was sent home on the written condition that he would not leave town .

    HYP: he was released home under a subscription for no-leave .


  1047. REF: this news was widely discussed on social networks and in the media , since , as of yet , there is no procedure in Russia for holding transgender people in pre-trial detention facilities and penal colonies .

    HYP: this news was widely discussed on social networks and media , as the transgender mechanism in custody and colonies in Rosalia does not exist .


  1048. REF: Russian human rights advocate and activist in the LGBT movement ( LGBT - lesbian , gay , bisexual , transgender ) , Nikolai Alekseev , supports the idea of creating special places for transgender people to serve out their sentences , noting that , abroad , it is also possible to place people in penal colonies - male or female - depending on their own preferences .

    HYP: the Russian human rights activist , activist of the LGBT movement ( lesbian , gay , bisexual , transsexuals ) , Nikolai Alexievich supported the idea of creating special places for the punishment of transgender people , noting that overseas it is also possible to define people in the colony - male or female - depending on their own desire .


  1049. REF: given the climate in Russian prisons , this is the correct recommendation .

    HYP: given the atmosphere in Russian prisons , the offer is correct .


  1050. REF: yes , it 's a very small percentage , but the problem is real , just as is the issue of ensuring the safety of homosexuals in prisons , says Alekseev .

    HYP: yes , it is a very small percentage , but the problem is there as well as the issue of security in prisons for homosexuals , '' Alexeev says .


  1051. REF: prisons should be safe ; therefore , separate blocs could be established for this sake , as well as for homosexuals , especially since there are more of them in prisons than transgender people .

    HYP: prisons should be safe , so individual blocks could be made in the name of this and for homosexuals , the more so that their prisons are more than transgender .


  1052. REF: moreover , Alekseev doubts that there will be a lot of citizens in Russia who will be ready to pass themselves off as transsexuals just to get into somewhere other than a regular penal colony .

    HYP: Alexeev doubts that in Russia there will be a lot of citizens ready to extradite themselves for transcologists for the sake of getting in an excellent colony .


  1053. REF: of course , a medical examination could be introduced before placing people into a penal colony for transgender people ; however , things are not always so straightforward .

    HYP: of course , it is possible to enter a medical examination before placing people in the colony for transgender people , but not always all is unequivocal .


  1054. REF: for example , in the US , one prisoner , Chelsea Manning , looked like a man , but once already in prison , announced that he wanted to change his sex , says Alekseev .

    HYP: for example , in the US , one of the prisoners , Chelsea Menning looked like a man and had already in prison declared he wanted to change gender , Alexeev said .


  1055. REF: a person can feel like they are anyone at all .

    HYP: a person can feel like anyone else .


  1056. REF: however , as of yet , there are no separate facilities for transgender people to serve out their sentences , and I doubt that prison staff will think seriously about the safety of such people or fathom the complexities of their orientation or gender identification .

    HYP: but while there are no places to be punished for transgender people , I doubt that prison staff will be thinking seriously about the safety of such people and getting into the nuances of their orientation or sexual identification .


  1057. REF: at the same time , international expert on issues of reproductive health in the Russian Federation , Boris Lordkipanidze , noted that the introduction of a new system for assigning transsexual criminals to a penal colony could significantly delay the start of the convicts serving their sentences .

    HYP: at the same time , the international expert on reproductive health at Russian Federation Boris Lhorutanidze noted that the introduction of a new distribution system for transgender offenders in the colony could severely delay the death of convicts .


  1058. REF: a committee is created : this is a question of sexology , with psychiatrists conducting long-term examinations - this is not just one test - on the basis of which a highly precise diagnosis is made .

    HYP: a commission is created - it is a matter of sexism , psychiatrists hold lengthy observations , it is not one test based on which is made a precise conclusion .


  1059. REF: modern practices in psychiatry make this possible .

    HYP: today 's opportunities for psychiatry allow this .


  1060. REF: this is why , before a sex change , potential patients undergo such expert evaluation ; they will definitively show whether or not a sex change requiring surgery is a necessary measure , says Lordkipanidze .

    HYP: therefore , and before the end of the sex , the potential patients have always had such an examination - they show exactly whether a change of sex with surgical intervention is necessary , '' says Lune boiled .


  1061. REF: however , it is difficult for me to imagine how to introduce this system in relation to convicted individuals ; after all , on average , it takes an entire month to conduct such an examination .

    HYP: however , it is hard for me to imagine how this system will be implemented in relation to the convict , because on average there is a month .


  1062. REF: the doctor , in spite of the fact that he supports the general idea of creating separate blocs for transsexuals , also doubts that it would be appropriate under current economic conditions to allocate funds towards the construction of new facilities and medical examinations : transgender people in Russia are few and far between .

    HYP: the doctor , although in general the idea of creating separate blocks for transgender people , also doubts that , under current economic conditions , it will be appropriate to allocate funds for building new premises , medical expertise , and transgender people in Russia .


  1063. REF: it 's difficult to come up with a number as there are no official statistics , but if one considers that homosexuals account for around 5 % , then it is fair to say that there are even fewer transgender people , and that those that have such an inclination and also commit crimes comprise an entirely small number , said Lordkipanidze .

    HYP: it is difficult to find out , there is no official statistics , but if we consider that homosexuals in Russia are about 5 % , it is possible to say that transgender people are even smaller , and those who have such a deviation and commit crimes are at least a small amount , '' said Lune boiled .

    HYP: now under the petition before the administration of the colony of homosexuals , transgender people and so can receive separate conditions of content .
