  1132. REF: as a tool for assessing the professional reputation of top Russian managers , the study takes stock of the work of Russian executives for the year , identifying leaders in industries and functional areas .

    HYP: as an instrument of evaluation of the professional reputation of Russian managers of the highest echelon , the survey summarizes the work of Russian managers for the year , revealing leaders in industries and functional areas .


  1133. REF: the initial pool of candidates consists of winners from last year 's rating .

    HYP: the initial pool of candidates is the winners of last year 's rating .


  1134. REF: winners from the previous year are asked to confirm their participation as a candidate in the current year 's rating and to nominate members from their own management team .

    HYP: the winners of the last year are invited to confirm their participation as a candidate of the current year and put members of their management team .


  1135. REF: moreover , each of those included in the initial list of candidates are invited to nominate up to ten new managers from other companies whom it would be advisable to add the general pool of candidates .

    HYP: in addition , each of the candidates included in the initial list of candidates propose to nominate up to ten new managers from other companies , which would be appropriate to add to the common pool of candidates .


  1136. REF: it is possible to nominate the following heads of functional areas of a company : financial director , commercial director , marketing director , human resources director , IT director , director of public and corporate relations , director of government relations , and director of corporate governance .

    HYP: it is possible to move the following heads of functional directions of the company : finance director , commercial director , director of marketing , director of staff , IT director , director on public and corporate relations , director of relations with authorities , director of corporate governance .


  1137. REF: each of the managers proposed by the experts is sent an invitation to participate in the rating and is given the opportunity to nominate their management team and up to ten new managers from other companies .

    HYP: each offered by the experts will be invited to participate in the rating and are given the opportunity to present their management team and up to ten new leaders from other companies .


  1138. REF: the nomination of candidates by sector is based on the Association of Managers ' industry classification : information technology , commercial banking , the forestry and wood processing industry , manufacturing , the media industry , the metal industry , multi-industry holdings , professional services , the communications and data industry , service and consumer goods production , insurance , construction , trade , transportation , the financial sector , pharmaceuticals , the chemical industry , and the energy and fuel complex .

    HYP: the selection of the candidates on the industry principle is carried out on the basis of branch classification of the Association of Managers : information technologies , commercial banks , forest and forest processing industry , machine building , media , insurance , construction , trade , transport , financial sector , pharmaceuticals , chemical industry , energy and fuel complex .


  1139. REF: each participant is given a username and password to log into the site , www.top1000.amr.ru , where they can find information about the other participants and submit their assessments according to the proposed criteria for each functional area .

    HYP: each participant will be provided with login and password to access the site www.top1000.amr.ru where they see the information about other participants and can set their evaluations on the criteria for each functional direction .


  1140. REF: the methodology for the rating is based on the principle of `` the best choosing the best '' : top managers rating top managers , and functional managers rating functional managers .

    HYP: the principle `` The best choose the best '' is based on the methodology of making a rating : top managers estimate the top managers , functional managers assess functional managers .


  1141. REF: such a principle makes it possible to obtain the most authentic assessment of the professional reputation of colleagues .

    HYP: such principle allows to obtain maximally authentic evaluation of the professional reputation of colleagues .


  1142. REF: the final results of the rating are approved at meetings of the expert commission .

    HYP: final results of rating are approved at meetings of expert commissions .


  1143. REF: all interested candidates of the current year 's rating and repeat candidates from previous years ' ratings are invited to attend the in-person meetings of the expert commission .

    HYP: to the table meetings of expert commissions are invited all wishing candidates of the current year and multiple candidates of the rating of the previous years .


  1144. REF: the commission is organised along functional lines : a commission for approving top managers and eight commissions for approving heads of functional departments .

    HYP: the commission is organized according to the function : the Commission approves the list of top managers and eight commissions on approval of the leaders of functional directions .


  1145. REF: at meetings of the expert commissions , the presented lists are to be approved in alphabetical order ( rankings are kept in strict accordance with the internet assessment and remain confidential until the publication of the rating ) , or updated changes are made to them in accordance with the enclosed list of reserve candidates .

    HYP: at meetings of expert commissions it is proposed to approve the presented lists in alphabetical order ( the places are kept strictly according to the Internet appraisal and are classified information prior to publication of the rating ) or make actualizing their adjustments according to the attached list of reserve candidates .


  1146. REF: company names are presented in accordance with Russian language rules and Kommersant standards .

    HYP: the names of the companies are given in accordance with the rules of the Russian language and the norms `` Kommersant . ''


  1147. REF: at the time of publication , changes to the status of managers and companies are possible .

    HYP: at the time of publishing the rating can be changed in the status of managers and companies .


  1148. REF: 10-13 % is a comfortable rate for investment loans .

    HYP: the comfortable rate for the loan is 10-13 % .


  1149. REF: according to experts , the credit market for small and medium businesses shrunk by 40 % between January and April of this year .

    HYP: according to experts , the credit market for small and medium business in January-April of this year woke up to 40 % .


  1150. REF: in your opinion , what is the situation like today ?

    HYP: what is your estimated situation today ?


  1151. REF: after the panicked mood at the end of 2014 and the beginning of 2015 , the volume of lending to SMEs declined significantly .

    HYP: after the panic of the end of 2014 - the beginning of 2015 volumes of credit volumes to SMEs decreased significantly .


  1152. REF: the reason is obvious : a sharp rise in interest rates .

    HYP: the reason is clear : a sharp rise in interest rates .


  1153. REF: financing at 25-30 % per annum was n't beneficial to anyone .

    HYP: lending under 25-30 % per annum was not beneficial to anyone .


  1154. REF: if previously , a bank could place all of its potential future problems , from arrears to defaults , at a higher rate , then now it is no longer possible to do this : the rates are already sky-high .

    HYP: if previously , the bank could lay down all its possible problems in the future , from late to return , it is impossible to do that : bets and so on .


  1155. REF: for the business community , the current level of interest rates for loans to SMEs is n't comfortable .

    HYP: for business the current level of rates on credit of SMEs is not comfortable .


  1156. REF: for a significant proportion of investment projects , the current level is unacceptable in terms of their rate of return .

    HYP: for a large part of investment projects , the current level is unacceptable in terms of their payback .


  1157. REF: an interest rate level of between 10-13 % would enable businesses to invest in a wide range of projects and make an attractive profit from them .

    HYP: a 10-13 per cent rate would allow businesses to invest in a wide range of projects and form an attractive yield on them .


  1158. REF: in your opinion , to what extent is the demand for credit by business owners being met ?

    HYP: how does your estimate be satisfied with the demand of entrepreneurs for loans ?


  1159. REF: the situation improved slightly after the Central Bank lowered the interest rate .

    HYP: the situation changed slightly after the Central Bank was lowered .


  1160. REF: credit resources became more readily available .

    HYP: credit resources have become more affordable .


  1161. REF: however , according to our observations , clients have started to apply for loans much more infrequently .

    HYP: however , according to our observations , customers began to ask for loans much less frequently .


  1162. REF: first of all , businesses ca n't discern the prospects for their development or future earnings .

    HYP: first of all , business does not understand the prospects of its development and future income .


  1163. REF: today , businesses have one option : they need to learn how to operate by focusing on the current economic situation in the country and the region .

    HYP: today one way out of business : it is necessary to learn how to work , focusing on the current economic situation in the country and region .


  1164. REF: it 's necessary to more closely monitor current performance and control cash flow .

    HYP: more closely follow current results , control the movement of cash .

    HYP: all this ultimately allows the company to make products more competitive and keep the business even in an unstable economic situation .

    HYP: in these countries he would like to remove one person and place the other , which will act in the interests of the Western countries , not in the interests of their Motherland , he noted .

    HYP: Assad has been paying attention to a sharp turn from the Western media since launching a coup in Ukraine .

    HYP: in his words , for them , Russian President Vladimir Putin `` turned from a friend of the West in an enemy , a king , a dictator who suppresses the Russian opposition , which has come to power by the undemocratic way , despite being elected as a result of democratic elections recognized in the West .     HYP: commenting on persistent claims by the West that Assad himself should leave , he noted that the president comes to power with the people 's consent , through elections , and if it leaves - on the demand of the people , not by the decision of the United States , the UN Security Council , the Geneva Conference , or the Geneva communiqué .

    HYP: reporting by Yasuman Abutaleb ; Editing by Christian plam


  1877. REF: for mildly obese diabetics , weight loss surgery may be helpful

    HYP: diabetic patients with little obesity can help surgery of obesity


  1878. REF: the benefits of weight loss surgery for mildly obese people with type 2 diabetes can last at least five years , according to a new study .

    HYP: a beneficial effect after surgery for obesity in people with little obesity , with type 2 diabetes , can last at least five years , according to a new study .


  1879. REF: it 's still to early to say whether mildly obese people with diabetes live longer after weight loss surgery than those who receive non-surgical treatments , however .

    HYP: however , it is now early to claim that diabetics with little obesity live longer after surgery for obesity than those who receive non-surgical treatment .


  1880. REF: `` The mortality data take a long time to show up , '' said Dr. Robin Blackstone , a weight loss surgery expert who wrote an editorial on the new study in JAMA Surgery .

    HYP: `` The statistics of mortality manifested not at once , '' said Dr. Robin Blexstone , an obesity surgeon , who wrote about the new study in the editor of JAMA Surgery .


  1881. REF: weight loss operations , or bariatric surgery , use various methods to shrink the size of the stomach .

    HYP: surgery for obesity , or bariatric surgery , uses different methods to reduce the size of the stomach .


  1882. REF: they reduce hunger and limit the body 's ability to absorb food .

    HYP: they reduce hunger and limit the ability of organisms to absorb food .


  1883. REF: over the years , bariatric surgeries have proved effective for treating type 2 diabetes , but most studies were done in people who are morbidly obese , with a body mass index ( BMI ) of 35 or above .

    HYP: for several years , bariatric surgery has proven to be effective for the treatment of type 2 diabetes , but basic research was conducted among people with morphine obesity having the body mass index ( IMT ) 35 or higher .


  1884. REF: BMI , a measure of weight in relation to height , is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9 .

    HYP: IMT , a measure of weight relative to growth , is considered normal at value from 18.5 to 24.9 .


  1885. REF: a BMI of 25 or higher indicates that someone is overweight , and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese .

    HYP: IMT 25 or above suggests that a person is overweight and people with IMT above 30 are considered people with obesity .


  1886. REF: you can calculate your BMI here : 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv .

    HYP: you can calculate your IMT here : 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv .


  1887. REF: for the new study , researchers from Taiwan 's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data collected since 2007 in a trial comparing two kinds of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were mildly obese .

    HYP: for the new study , researchers from Min-Sheng General 's Taiwan hospital have used data collected since 2007 to compare two types of bariatric surgery - Shuning of stomach and elongated gastocomia , with a medical treatment of 2 diabetes patients with little obesity .


  1888. REF: the average BMI among those who had surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of their fifth year in the study .

    HYP: the average value of IMT among those undergoing surgery has fallen from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of their involvement in the study .


  1889. REF: meanwhile , the BMI among those receiving non-surgical diabetes treatments stayed about the same at 29 .

    HYP: at the same time the BMI of those who received non-surgical treatment from diabetes remains at about 29 .


  1890. REF: among those who had surgery , diabetes resolved completely in 36 percent and partially in 28 percent .

    HYP: among those who suffered the surgery fully cured of diabetes by 36 % , and partially - 28 % .


  1891. REF: in the medically-treated group , by comparison , diabetes resolved completely in only 1 percent and partially in only about 2 percent .

    HYP: in a group receiving drug treatment , for comparison , the total cure for diabetes was only 1 % , and a partial one - only about 2 % .


  1892. REF: in addition , control of blood pressure , triglycerides , and `` bad '' LDL cholesterol `` was generally better in the surgical group , '' the authors found .

    HYP: in addition , blood pressure levels , triglycerides and `` bad '' LPNP cholesterol were `` generally better in the surgical group , '' the authors claim .


  1893. REF: the researchers also monitored patients ' blood levels of hemoglobin A1c , which reflect blood sugar levels over time .

    HYP: the researchers also monitored the levels of haemoglobin blood cells that reflect levels of sugar in the blood in the dynamics .


  1894. REF: hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent , the researchers write .

    HYP: hemoglobin A1c better hold below 7 % , '' the researchers write .


  1895. REF: after surgery , the average hemoglobin A1c level fell from about 9 percent to about 6 percent .

    HYP: after surgery the average level of hemoglobin A1c reduced from about 9 % to about 6 % .


  1896. REF: in the medical therapy group , however , it remained steady at about 8 percent .

    HYP: in a therapeutic group , however , it remained stable , about 8 % .


  1897. REF: but this better `` glycemic control '' - as reflected by the improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the mortality rate at five years , according to lead researcher Dr. Chih-cheng Hsu and colleagues .

    HYP: but the best indicators of glycemic control , reflected in good levels of hemoglobin A1c , have not reduced the death rate in five years , according to the head of research by Dr. Chi-Cheng Su and colleagues .


  1898. REF: the research team also compared average outcomes with the two types of surgery .

    HYP: the research team also compared the average outcomes of two types of surgical treatment .


  1899. REF: at the fifth year , compared to the sleeve gastrectomy group , the bypass surgery group had lost more weight ( 18.7 vs 14.2 kg ) , achieved larger drops in BMI ( 7.4 vs 5.1 ) and in hemoglobin A1c ( 3.1 percent vs 2.1 percent ) and were more likely to have complete diabetes remission ( 46.9 percent vs 16.7 percent ) .

    HYP: for the fifth year , in comparison with the band polled by a sleeveless touring band , the shuncing group lost more weight ( 18.7 kg against 14.2 kg ) , achieved a larger reduction of IMT ( at 7.4 vs. 5.1 ) and hemoglobin versus ( 3.1 % vs. 2.1 % ) , and was closer to the full remission of diabetes ( 46.9 % vs. 16.7 % ) .


  1900. REF: while the new study does not show a survival benefit or surgery after five years , there is evidence from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery does lead to a longer life , says Blackstone , of the University of Arizona College of Medicine-Phoenix .

    HYP: although the new study does not show the benefits of the surgical method in part of life expectancy after five years , there are confirmation of the results of a study of patients with an overweight body in Sweden that surgical treatment actually leads to an increase in life expectancy , as reported by Blexstone from the College of Medicine in Phoenix , the University of Arizona .


  1901. REF: in the Swedish study , obese people who had bariatric surgery were about 29 percent less likely to die over 15 years , compared to a group who tried more conventional methods .

    HYP: according to a Swedish study for people with obesity , who pushed the bariatric intervention , the chance to die for 15 years was about 29 % lower compared to the group in which more traditional methods were applied .


  1902. REF: though the new study did n't show a benefit in survival among surgery patients , Blackstone said it 's reassuring for people with a BMI under 35 interested in the procedure .

    HYP: although the new study showed no increase in life expectancy , Blatter noted that it encouraged people with IMT below 35 , interested in such a procedure .


  1903. REF: `` This is where this paper is critical , because it says this surgery is safe in that lower BMI group , '' with no increased risk of death or renal disease , she said .

    HYP: `` This report is very important , because it claims to be safe in a low BMI group where there is no increased risk of mortality or kidney disease , '' she said .


  1904. REF: Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously once the patient 's BMI falls between 27 and 30 .

    HYP: Blatter added that people and their doctors should start to seriously treat the weight as a patient 's BMI falls into the range between 27 and 30 .


  1905. REF: `` I think we wait too long to get people to be serious about this , '' she said .

    HYP: `` I believe we take too long to get people to treat this seriously , '' she said .


  1906. REF: I think that once they 've accumulated these genetic changes that hardwired their bodies into obesity and diabetes , reversing that is really hard .

    HYP: it seems to me that once they have accumulated genetic changes that run into their bodies of obesity and diabetes , reverse is very difficult .

  1930. REF: in other words , there may be more hotels that have undergone classification , but no one knows about it .

    HYP: that is , there may be more or more classifications , but nobody knows about it .

    HYP: `` For the last six months , hotels have not been very keen to undergo classification , '' acknowledged the director of the North-West branch of the Russian Union of Tourism Ekaterina Shadskaya .

    HYP: this is explained by the high season , during which the hoteliers earn the most money and do not want to engage in other activities .

    HYP: another reason is the budgets that have not been put into account , and the procedure may cost the hotel depending on the status of between 30 and 100 thousand rubles and more .

    HYP: however , at the last time the heads of the hotels became activated and began to apply for classification , wrapped Shadskaya .

    HYP: hotels must have time before July 1 , 2016 , otherwise they will not only pay a fine , but will also not get the right to work in the World Cup .

    HYP: this is done in order to avoid a rise in prices by 200-300 % , as it happens , for example during the St. Petersburg Economic Forum .

  2432. REF: HP is splitting into two listed companies later this year , separating its computer and printer businesses from its faster-growing corporate hardware and services operations .

    HYP: in the same year , Hewlett-Packard is divided into two registered companies , separating the production of computers and printers from more rapidly developing hardware and service operations .


  2433. REF: the expected job cuts will result in a charge of about $ 2.7bn , beginning in the fourth quarter , HP said in a statement .

    HYP: deductions from the expected job cuts will amount to an estimated $ 2.7 billion since the fourth quarter , Hewlett-Packard said in a statement .


  2434. REF: `` These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive , sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise , '' said Meg Whitman , the HP chairman and chief executive who will head the unit after the split .

    HYP: `` This restructuring will provide a more competitive , sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise , '' said Meg Uitman , Chairman and CEO of Hewlett Packard , who will lead the organization after separation .


  2435. REF: `` Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP is today , and we will have a broad and deep portfolio of businesses that will help enterprises transition to the new style of business , '' said Whitman .

    HYP: `` Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than Hewlett-Packard at present , and the portfolio of business will be wider and deeper , which will help move the company into a new style of business , '' said Uitman .


  2436. REF: as a separate company , we are better positioned than ever to meet the evolving needs of our customers around the world .

    HYP: as a standalone company we are in a better position than before to respond to the growing requests of our customers around the world .

    HYP: in order to demonstrate them , Maskin alters four skills of specialists - A and B for rich countries , C and D - for the poor .


  2801. REF: after globalisation , the D specialists from poor countries do n't have the required skill level to cooperate with specialists A and B from wealthy countries .

    HYP: after globalization , experts from poor countries lack the level of qualification to cooperate with specialists A and B from rich countries .


  2802. REF: and while the wages of C level workers from poor countries rise thanks to cooperation with B colleagues from wealthy ones , D workers either do n't experience the same effect or their salaries totally plunge .

    HYP: and , if lower-income workers from poor countries are growing up due to cooperation with the employees of the B from the rich , they do not feel either their wages down at all .


  2803. REF: the resulting effect is that the internationalisation of production will lead to an increase in the wage gap between these two categories of specialists in poor countries and , consequently , increased levels of inequality .

    HYP: the final effect is that the internationalization of production will increase the wage gap between the two categories of specialists in poor countries and accordingly to increase the level of inequality .


  2804. REF: Kremer and E. Maksin have proposed a remarkably beautiful model , an alternative to the Ricardian theory of comparative advantage .

    HYP: Kremer and E. Maskin offer a surprisingly beautiful model , alternative to the rikardian theory of comparative advantage .


  2805. REF: it makes it possible to explain why globalisation has led to income inequality , says Fuad Aleskerov , tenured professor , Head of the International Laboratory of Decision Choice and Analysis , and Head of the Department of Mathematics at NRI HSE .

    HYP: it allows to explain why globalization has led to income inequality , '' said Fuad Alesorov , an ordinary professor , head of the International Laboratory of Analysis and Choice of Solutions , the head of the Institute of Mathematics , NIU VSHE .


  2806. REF: and , like any powerful theory , I am sure it will lead to an upsurge of empirical work in this field .

    HYP: and as any powerful theory is , I am sure that it will lead to an outbreak of empirical work in this area .


  2807. REF: the solution to the problem , in Eric Maksin 's opinion , is to improve the level of education of low-skilled workers .

    HYP: the solution to the problem , according to Eric Maskin , is to raise the level of education of low-skilled workers .


  2808. REF: however , the workers themselves , the academic notes , do n't have the money for this , and it 's not profitable for companies to pay for their training .

    HYP: however , employees like the scientist do not have funds , and companies are not profitable to pay for their training .


  2809. REF: in a situation like this , governments , international agencies , NGOs , and private foundations can play a significant role , Maksin believes .

    HYP: governments , international agencies , NGOs and private funds can play a significant role , Maskin believes .


  2810. REF: the academic notes that the developed theory in no way calls for an end to the process of globalisation , which has brought and will bring benefits in the form of GDP growth of countries .

    HYP: the scientist points out that the developed theory does not , in any case , call for a halt to the process of globalization , which has brought and yields fruit in the form of GDP growth .


  2811. REF: Derbent : a living link with time .

    HYP: Derbent : live connection of times .

    HYP: Derbent - one of the most ancient cities of Russia - in September marks its 2000-anniversary .


  2813.     HYP: Derbent is the only Russian city that has preserved its place since ancient times .

    HYP: although the Roman Empire , Byzantium , Khazar Haganat and the Golden Horde were used to it .

  2916. REF: the problem is especially acute in large metropolitan areas where the development of infrastructure is lagging behind rapid urbanisation : cities are blanketed by thick smog , rivers are filled with pesticides and industrial and household waste , and the few remaining residential areas are being razed to build new residential neighbourhoods .

    HYP: the problem is particularly acute in large mega cities , where infrastructure development does not lead to rapid urbanization : cities are covered with dense smog , rivers are filled with pesticides and waste of enterprises and households , and few remaining dwellings are cut under construction of new residential quarters .

    HYP: so , in May this year , the environment minister called the court 's decisions `` extreme '' and `` impossible . ''

    HYP: sometimes a court decision really can not be executed in the given court date , confirms the lawyer for environmental affairs Radha Pandjwani .


  2920. REF: however , impossible deadlines have an upside : at least they force the responsible parties to get cracking .

    HYP: however , unfulfilled grandparents have a positive side : at least they are forcing the responsible people to move .


  2921. REF: `` Its main purpose is to shake up this system '' , the lawyer adds .

    HYP: `` His main goal is to shake up this system , '' the lawyer added .


  2922. REF: the Green Tribunal has already cancelled major projects on several occasions : construction of an airport , an electrical power station , and hundreds of other smaller facilities has been terminated on its account .

    HYP: the Green Tribunal has repeatedly cancelled the major construction projects : on its account the termination of the construction of the airport , power station and hundreds of smaller structures .

    HYP: but such explanations do not always find understanding among ordinary people whose lives can change thanks to a single scrap of referee pen .

    HYP: Xi Jinping calls to make economy more open to peace

    HYP: the economy should become more open to the whole world to spur its growth , as President Xi Jinping said on Tuesday in an address to the group ahead of the challenge to the reform guide .


  2986. REF: `` China should be committed to attracting foreign investment and expertise , and improve opening-up policies , '' he said , addressing the 16th Meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform .

    HYP: `` China should concentrate on attracting foreign investors and experts and developing a policy of openness , '' he said , addressing the participants of the 16th meeting of the Central Front Committee for comprehensive deepening of reforms .


  2987. REF: promoting opening up while pushing forward reforms will add new impetus and vitality , and provide new room for economic growth , Xi said .

    HYP: he said that increasing openness and deepening reforms would give the economy a new impetus and vitality and provide a new space for economic development .


  2988. REF: the leading group adopted a series of guidelines including a negative list regulating market access , relaxation of border-control policies , encouraging state-owned enterprises ( SOE ) to absorb private capital and overhauling the resident registration system .

    HYP: the leading group has adopted a number of directives , including introducing the regulation of investor access to the market , changing border controls , the encouragement of state-owned enterprises ( SOE ) , attracting private capital and revising the registration system for residents .


  2989. REF: according to the statement , a negative list , identifying sectors and businesses that are off-limits for investment , will be drawn up .

    HYP: according to the statement , a list of sectors of economy and production , inaccessible to investment , will be drawn up .


  2990. REF: the system will be gradually tested and improved through trial programs .

    HYP: the system will be gradually worked out through trial programs .


  2991. REF: the move is significant as it will give the market a bigger role in allocating resources , ensuring a law-based business environment and making the market more open , the statement said .

    HYP: this is an important step , as it will give the market a more significant role in the allocation of resources , ensuring legitimacy in business and increased openness , as the statement said .


  2992. REF: the government will also loosen controls on the powers it delegates to companies , making sure that companies decide how to run their businesses .

    HYP: the government will also weaken control of the powers given to them by firms , ensuring that companies themselves will run their business .


  2993. REF: the statement also said China will allow border areas to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms for promoting regional growth .

    HYP: the statement also said that China would allow border regions to master new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to boost local growth .


  2994. REF: in a bid to open up state-controlled sectors , more areas will be open to private investment .

    HYP: more areas will be made available to private investors in order to improve the openness of the state-controlled sectors of the economy .


  2995. REF: `` The government will not change its policy toward foreign investment , and will protect the lawful interests of foreign-funded companies and provide better services for them , '' said the statement .

    HYP: `` The government will not change its policy towards foreign investors and will protect the legitimate interests of companies with foreign financing , and provide them with better conditions , '' the statement said .


  2996. REF: in addition , it will be made easier for foreigners to apply for permanent residence permits , or `` green card , '' by optimizing requirements and streamlining the application process .

    HYP: in addition there will be a simplified procedure for applying for permanent residence permit , or `` grin-card , '' by optimizing requirements and simplifying the process of the application process .


  2997. REF: guaranteeing lawyers ' right to practice and nurturing professional judges and prosecutors were also discussed at a meeting .

    HYP: the meeting also discussed the protection of lawyers ' rights and questions of training of professional judges and prosecutor 's office .


  2998. REF: the meeting was also attended by Premier Li Keqiang , and senior leaders Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli , according to a statement released after the meeting .

    HYP: according to the official report released after the meeting , Prime Minister Li Keqiang and ministers Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli were also present .
